Vice President Mike Pence is keeping his distance from President Donald Trump for "a few days," White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany said Tuesday, following a Pence staffer's testing positive for the coronavirus last week. McEnany told reporters that the length of time Pence distances from Trump is up to the vice president. The White House announced Friday that Pence's press secretary, Katie Miller, had tested positive. She is married to Stephen Miller, a top Trump adviser.

title: Trump estimates 95,000 or more coronavirus deaths in U.S.
description:
President Donald Trump on Friday said the U.S. coronavirus death toll may be 95,000 or more. "We may be talking about 95,000 people, ultimately," Trump said at a White House meeting with Republican lawmakers. "We may be talking about something more than that," he said. The U.S. currently has the world's highest case toll at 1.26 million, and the highest death toll at 76,032.

title: Trump says he's having 'a very hard time with China' in Friday Fox News interview
description:
President Donald Trump on Friday said he's having "a very hard time with China" and hasn't decided how to handle the trade relationship. Trump spoke in a Fox News interview, after top trade representatives from both sides discussed their phase-one trade deal Thursday night. Trump has threatened sanctions against China over its handling of the coronavirus outbreak, but made no such threat in the interview Friday. He also called the 20.5 million jobs lost in April "no surprise" and that it was fully expected. Trump has predicted the economy will "transition" in the third quarter. U.S. stock futures were up more than 200 points Friday after the jobs report.

title: Justice Department dropping criminal case against Trump national-security adviser Flynn: AP
description:
The Justice Department on Thursday said it is dropping the criminal case against President Donald Trump's first national-security adviser, Michael Flynn, the Associated Press reported. Flynn's prosecution became a rallying cry for Trump and his supporters in attacking the FBI's Russia investigation, as the AP writes. The Justice Department said it is dropping the case "after a considered review of all the facts and circumstances of this case, including newly discovered and disclosed information," reports the AP.
